author: Tom Loftus
title: The Morning Download: New Chip Flaw Related to Spectre and Meltdown Emerges
text:
6 COMMENTS Photo: STEINBA/EPA/SHUTTERSTOCK

Subscribe to WSJ Pro Cybersecurity for in-depth coverage on cybersecurity trends, breaches and best practices. Good morning, CIOs. Researchers have identified a new security flaw affecting nearly almost all modern processors. For those experiencing a sense déjà vu, the flaw is a variant of Spectre and Meltdown, chip flaws first announced in January that were found to exploit a technique used to speed chip processing.
Similar to Spectre and Meltdown , the Speculative Store Bypass or “Variant 4,” touches upon processors from Intel Corp ., Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and ARM Holdings , targeting the same process, called speculative execution, where chips perform calculations out of order to speed performance.
The good-ish news . Researchers tell Reuters that risks are lower, because of the prevalence of patches created earlier to address Spectre. But because the patches address a flaw in how chips process data, fixes have resulted in performance sluggishness. Writes Wired : “Once companies push all the various types of updates, though, users will decide case by case whether to install them, since bypassing processing efficiencies to neuter potential attacks can also slow systems down… For SSB—which seems like it may be a less dangerous bug—some users may consider the pros and cons of patching rather than immediately moving forward.”
Warren Buffett’s insurance company finds global benefits from the cloud. “We’re not going to stand up a technology platform that is unique to Asia and stand up a team in Asia,” Jamie Roser, CIO of Berkshire Hathaway Specialty Insurance, tells CIO Journal’s Steven Norton . “We want to leverage platforms globally and figure out how to make them support the global needs.”
PRIVACY + SECURITY
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg speaks at the company’s annual F8 developers conference in San Jose, Calif., on May 1. Photo: STEPHEN LAM/REUTERS
Zuckerberg enters the lion’s den: Privacy-focused Europe. Top European lawmakers are set to interrogate Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg on Tuesday over the company’s handling of alleged user-data misuse and election interference on the platform, the WSJ reports . Mr. Zuckerberg will likely also face questions over how the social network will comply with the EU’s new privacy law. The live-streamed event starts in Brussels around 6:30 p.m. local time, or 12:30 p.m. ET.
In phone use, Trump goes against security best practices. Politico reports that the president has gone as long as five months without having his phone checked by security experts. Another security risk: the phone’s camera and microphone remain activiated.
North Korea hacks for profit. Agents acting on behalf of the regime may have stolen up to $650 million through cyberattacks, a consultant for South Korea’s National Intelligence Service said recently. Quartz has the story .
CRYPTOCURRENCIES
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission building in Washington Photo: STEPHEN VOSS FOR THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
CFTC issues new guidance on cryptocurrency derivatives. As the Journal’s Gabriel T. Rubin reports , bitcoin’s volatility and worries about bitcoin exchanges’ lack of transparency and cyber vulnerability have caused some on Wall Street, including the Futures Industry Association, to call on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to take a harder look at virtual currency derivatives before allowing them to come to market.
The Russian crypto connection. More often than not the CEO or founder of ICO-seeking projects hails from Russia. What gives? The country is rich in engineering talent, partly the result of the previous Soviet era emphasis on science and mathematics, but access to venture capital is limited, Quartz reports . The result: Russia’s crypto pioneers look west.
MORE TECHNOLOGY NEWS
HP Chief Executive Dion Weisler says he has focused the company on higher-margin businesses such as gaming machines. Photo: JASON ALDEN/BLOOMBERG NEWS
HP chalks success where it can find it. By focusing on sleeker designs and high-performance gaming machines, HP Inc. has managed to boost revenue and gobble market share from smaller competitors even as the PC market shrank, the Journal’s Jay Green reports . Now, with the PC market largely condensed into a handful of giants, the questions for HP are how long it can make the formula last and what comes next.
AWS expands in Latin America. The cloud service’s Buenos Aires office, opened in April, joins offices in Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Mexico, Reuters reports .
Big Ag meets AI robots. The days of indiscrimantely spraying crops with herbicides may be over as robots, kitted with AI-enabled visual recognition systems, take to the fields to identify weeds and spray as needed. Reuters reports that a number of big concerns, including Bayer AG and Deere & Co ., are seeking partners or acquistion targets in an effort to develop their own precision-spraying systems.
U.S., China agree on outline to settle ZTE controversy. If completed, the Trump administration would remove the ban on U.S. companies selling components and software to ZTE Corp. , a penalty that has threatened to put the company out of business, the WSJ’s Lingling Wei and Bob Davis report . Instead, ZTE would be forced to make big changes in management, board seats and possibly pay significant fines, the people said.
VC seeks to make cities smarter. The Journal’s Cat Zakrzewski reports that Palo Alto, Calif.-based Social Capital will back up to 10 startups addressing problems identified in collaboration with 100 Resilient Cities, a Rockefeller Foundation-backed initiative focused on helping cities anticipate and adapt to challenges ranging from inefficient transportation to chronic water shortages.
Consumer Reports rips into Tesla. The product-rating magazine declined to recommend the Tesla Model 3 sedan, equating its braking with that of a full-sized pickup truck, Reuters reports .
Uber’s new rules on arbitration for sex-related claims face first test. Less than a week after Uber Technologies Inc. announced a new policy freeing employees, customers and drivers to sue it in open court, a former Uber software engineer is suing the ride-hailing firm alleging years of sexual harassment, race discrimination and pay inequity. The Journal’s Greg Bensinger has more .
Bad social credit? No traveling. China’s state-run news outlet says the goverment’s social credit system, which dings citizens for a number of infractions, from jaywalking to not paying off loans, has succeeded in blocking people from taking 11 million flights and 4 million train trips, Business Insider reports that it is not clear what infractions merited inclusion on the travel blacklists.
EVERYTHING ELSE YOU NEED TO KNOW
President Trump met with top Justice Department officials about the use of an informant in the initial probe of Russian meddling in the 2016 election. (WSJ)
Starbucks tried to dig itself out of controversy by attempting to clarify a policy toward nonpaying guests. (WSJ)
General Electric Co. agreed to merge its railroad business with Wabtec Corp. in a deal valued at roughly $11 billion.
The New York Stock Exchange is set to get its first female leader in its 226-year history . Stacey Cunningham, the NYSE’s chief operating officer, will become the Big Board’s 67th president. (WSJ)
